sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Indonesia is the world’s largest archipelagic country, located in Southeast Asia. It consists of over 17,000 islands and is known for its cultural diversity, rich natural resources, and strategic maritime position.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Jakarta is the capital city of Indonesia and its main political, economic, and cultural center. The country plans to move its capital to Nusantara in East Kalimantan.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency of Indonesia is the Indonesian rupiah (IDR).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Indonesian (Bahasa Indonesia), which unites the country’s many ethnic and linguistic groups.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Indonesian cuisine is flavorful and diverse, with popular dishes including nasi goreng, rendang, satay, and gado-gado.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Indonesia lies along the Pacific Ring of Fire and has volcanoes, tropical rainforests, coral reefs, and fertile agricultural land.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Indonesian culture reflects a mix of indigenous traditions, Hindu-Buddhist heritage, Islamic influence, and European colonial history.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Major tourist destinations include Bali, Borobudur Temple, Komodo National Park, Raja Ampat, and Mount Bromo.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Indonesia has more active volcanoes than any other country in the world.

history.event: The Srivijaya Empire emerged as a powerful maritime kingdom controlling trade routes in Southeast Asia.
The Majapahit Empire rose to prominence, uniting much of the Indonesian archipelago.
European powers arrived, beginning with the Portuguese, followed by the Dutch.
The Dutch East Indies came under direct control of the Dutch government.
Japan occupied Indonesia during World War II.
The Netherlands officially recognized Indonesia’s independence.
Suharto became president, ushering in the New Order period.
The Reformasi era began after Suharto stepped down, leading to democratic reforms.
